questions.text:
A 30-year-old White woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of diarrhea and abdominal bloating. During this period, she has also had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss without changing her diet or trying to lose weight and reports increasing fatigue and intermittent tingling in her hands and feet. She and her husband have been trying to conceive for over a year without any success. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last for 1–2 days. She has generalized anxiety disorder for which she takes sertraline. She is 151 cm (4 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
7.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7900/mm3



Platelet count
180,000/mm3



Serum



 Glucose
95 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.6 mg/dL


 Thyroid-stimulating hormone
3.3 μU/mL


 Vitamin B12


80 pg/mL (N > 200)


 IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase

negative


 IgA

4 mg/dL


Stool testing for occult blood, ova, and parasites discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: IgG deamidated gliadin peptide antibody test

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Zinc deficiency may rarely occur in patients with CD as a result of intestinal malabsorption but is not a routine part of the workup of the condition. Regardless, adults with zinc deficiency usually present with dermatitis, which is not present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

A duodenal biopsy is required to definitively diagnose CD. However, given the cost and invasive nature of this procedure, another less invasive test should be conducted before confirming the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Qualitative and/or quantitative fecal fat tests are used to confirm the diagnosis of steatorrhea and are helpful in evaluating patients with malabsorption syndrome and fat-soluble vitamin deficiency due to an unclear cause. While steatorrhea may be present in patients with CD, a positive fecal fat test is non-specific as it can occur in multiple other conditions (e.g., chronic pancreatitis, hepatobiliary disease) and hence of little diagnostic value in the workup of this patient.

D) CORRECT:

The most appropriate initial test in the workup of suspected CD is IgA-based serology for tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-tTG). However, IgA-based testing can give false-negative results in patients with SIgAD. In these patients, IgG-based testing for anti-tTG or antibodies against deamidated gliadin peptide (anti-DGP) is the most appropriate initial test. In patients with positive serology for anti-tTG or anti-DGP, the diagnosis of CD is subsequently confirmed by esophagogastroduodenoscopy and duodenal biopsy.

Titers of anti-tTG and anti-DGP decrease if the patient adheres to a gluten-free diet and can be used to monitor treatment adherence.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-endomysial antibodies (EMAs) are antibodies produced against a special form of the enzyme transglutaminase that is present in the endomysium of intestinal smooth muscle. In the workup of CD, EMA serology is not performed as an initial test because it is expensive and difficult to interpret properly; this test may be used to confirm the diagnosis if the initial workup is inconclusive. Moreover, IgA-based testing should be avoided in this patient with SIgAD because of the risk of false-negative results.

F) INCORRECT:

Although skin prick tests are used to evaluate patients with suspected allergic disorders/atopy, they are not indicated in the diagnosis of CD.
questions.hint: Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause intermittent fatigue and pallor (due to anemia) and paresthesias. Celiac disease (CD), the symptoms of which can begin at any age, is the most likely cause in this white patient with chronic diarrhea, features of a malabsorption syndrome (e.g., vitamin B12 deficiency, weight loss), and infertility. Selective IgA deficiency (SIgAD) is the most common primary immunodeficiency and the prevalence of SIgAD in patients with CD is approx. 10–15 times higher than the prevalence in the general population.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman with Turner syndrome comes to the physician because of diarrhea for the past 4 months. She also reports bloating, nausea, and abdominal discomfort that persists after defecation. For the past six months, she has felt tired and has been unable to do her normal chores. She went on a backpacking trip across Southeast Asia around seven months ago. She is 144 cm (4 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 40 kg (88 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows pale conjunctivae and angular stomatitis. Abdominal examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.1 mg/dL


Leukocyte count
5100/mm3



Platelet count
200,000/mm3



Mean corpuscular volume
67 μmm3


Serum



Na+

136 mEq/L


K+

3.7 mEq/L


Cl-

105 mEq/L


Glucose
89 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.2 mg/dL


 Ferritin

8 ng/mL


 IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody

positive


Based on the laboratory studies, a biopsy for confirmation of the diagnosis is suggested, but the patient is unwilling to undergo the procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's gastrointestinal symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Probiotic therapy can be used for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), among other conditions. Although IBS can cause abdominal discomfort, it is not associated with a positive IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody or Turner syndrome, and would not cause iron deficiency anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Tetracyclines are used to treat tropical sprue, which can manifest very similar to celiac disease, typically beginning with an acute attack before settling into a chronic phase. However, the patient's risk factors and a positive IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody make another diagnosis more likely. A biopsy would conclusively rule out tropical sprue, but the patient has refused to undergo one.

C) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is indicated for giardiasis, which typically manifests with symptoms similar to the ones seen in this patient and is common in Southeast Asia. However, the incubation period is 7–14 days, meaning her symptoms should have begun soon after her trip. It also would not explain this patient's positive IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody.

D) INCORRECT:

Sulfasalazine is a first-line therapy for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). However, this patient does not have the classic symptoms associated with either Crohn disease (abdominal pain due to perianal abscesses/fistulas) or ulcerative colitis (bloody stool). Uveitis, arthritis, and skin manifestations such as pyoderma gangrenosum, are common in both ulcerative colitis and Crohn disease. Furthermore, IBD is not associated with a positive IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody or Turner syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Milk products can cause gastrointestinal symptoms in individuals with lactose intolerance, which would be unlikely in a woman without a history indicating lactose intolerance at an earlier age. Additionally, lactose intolerance is not associated with a positive IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody or Turner syndrome, and would very rarely cause iron deficiency anemia in adults.

F) INCORRECT:

IVIG therapy is used to treat common variable immunodeficiency (CVID). CVID results in recurrent infections due to markedly reduced IgG, IgA, and/or IgM levels. The patient's history is not consistent with CVID. Moreover, a positive IgA TTGA would be very unlikely in a disease characterized by reduced antibody levels.

G) CORRECT:

A lifelong gluten-free diet is the treatment of choice for celiac disease. Normally, the next step in diagnosis would be a biopsy. However, if the patient could not receive a biopsy (either because of a contraindication or personal preference), then an empiric trial of a gluten-free diet would be the most appropriate next step. The patient's response will then help to either confirm or reject the diagnosis of celiac disease.

Patients with chromosomal syndromes, like Turner syndrome, often have associated celiac disease.
Image Description:

The ingestion of gliadin, a component of gluten, leads to an immune response in the intestinal epithelium in individuals with celiac disease. Gliadin is deamidated by tissue transglutaminase (tTG) and then ingested by antigen-presenting cells (APC), which activate T cells via MHC II receptors. The activated T cell then activates plasma cells to release anti-tTG, anti-endomysial, and anti-deamidated gliadin antibodies (which all function as diagnostic markers of celiac disease). T cells also differentiate into TH1 cells, which activate cytoplasmic fibroblasts to release matrix proteases. This leads to the destruction of the intestinal architecture with villus atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and the loss of the brush border.

H) INCORRECT:

TMP-SMX is used to treat Whipple disease, which has a highly variable presentation but commonly manifests with diarrhea and gastrointestinal symptoms. Whipple disease, however, typically involves extraintestinal symptoms such as arthritis and is not associated with a positive IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody.
questions.hint: This patient has diarrhea, abdominal bloating, signs of iron deficiency anemia (e.g., fatigue, pale conjunctivae, angular stomatitis), and a positive IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody, indicating celiac disease.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of foul-smelling diarrhea, fatigue, and bloating for 6 months. During this time, he has had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss without a change in diet. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus that is well-controlled with insulin. Examination shows conjunctival pallor and inflammation of the corners of the mouth. The abdomen is soft, and there is diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.4 g/dL. The patient undergoes upper endoscopy. A photomicrograph of tissue from an intestinal biopsy is shown. Which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Avoidance of certain types of cereal grains

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Foul-smelling diarrhea, fatigue, bloating, unintentional weight loss, abdominal tenderness, and signs of iron deficiency anemia (low hemoglobin, conjunctival pallor, angular cheilitis) might raise concern for Whipple disease, which is treated with ceftriaxone. Although duodenal biopsy in Whipple disease may reveal blunting of the villi, it would also show foamy PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria rather than the lymphocytic infiltration seen in this patient. Moreover, Whipple disease is also associated with cardiac symptoms (e.g., valve insufficiencies), arthralgias, and neurological findings (e.g., myoclonia, ataxia, oculomotor impairment), none of which are seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Foul-smelling diarrhea, fatigue, bloating, unintentional weight loss, abdominal tenderness, and signs of iron and/or vitamin B12 deficiency (low hemoglobin, conjunctival pallor, angular cheilitis) might raise concern for Crohn disease (CD), which can be treated with infliximab. However, CD is not associated with villous atrophy or crypt hyperplasia on intestinal biopsy. Instead, histologic findings of CD include noncaseating granulomas, giant cells, neutrophilic inflammation of the crypts, and distinct lymphoid aggregates within the lamina propria.

C) CORRECT:

Foul-smelling diarrhea, fatigue, bloating, unintentional weight loss, abdominal tenderness, and features of iron deficiency anemia (low hemoglobin, conjunctival pallor, angular cheilitis) should raise suspicion for celiac disease, for which type 1 diabetes mellitus is a risk factor. The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of characteristic histology findings together with positive celiac serology. While the disease can occur at any age, the age of onset follows a bimodal distribution; it most often affects infants and adults in the 3rd and 4th decade of life. Treatment consists of a lifelong gluten-free diet, including avoidance of certain types of cereal grains such as wheat, rye, barley, and spelt.
Image Description:

The ingestion of gliadin, a component of gluten, leads to an immune response in the intestinal epithelium in individuals with celiac disease. Gliadin is deamidated by tissue transglutaminase (tTG) and then ingested by antigen-presenting cells (APC), which activate T cells via MHC II receptors. The activated T cell then activates plasma cells to release anti-tTG, anti-endomysial, and anti-deamidated gliadin antibodies (which all function as diagnostic markers of celiac disease). T cells also differentiate into TH1 cells, which activate cytoplasmic fibroblasts to release matrix proteases. This leads to the destruction of the intestinal architecture with villus atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and the loss of the brush border.

D) INCORRECT:

Diarrhea, fatigue, bloating, unintentional weight loss, abdominal tenderness, and signs of iron deficiency anemia (low hemoglobin, conjunctival pallor, angular cheilitis) might raise concern for ulcerative colitis (UC), which can be cured with surgical resection of the affected part of the colon. However, UC typically manifests with bloody diarrhea and only affects the colon, never the small intestine. Colonic biopsy in UC would show mucosal and submucosal inflammation and neutrophilic inflammation of the crypts.

E) INCORRECT:

Foul-smelling diarrhea, bloating, unintentional weight loss, and abdominal tenderness may be consistent with lactose intolerance, which is managed by avoiding or reducing the intake of lactose-containing milk products. However, lactose intolerance is not typically associated with signs of iron deficiency anemia (conjunctival pallor, low hemoglobin, angular cheilitis), which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, intestinal biopsy in lactose intolerance would show normal intestinal architecture, rather than the pathological findings seen in this patient's biopsy.

F) INCORRECT:

Foul-smelling diarrhea, fatigue, bloating, unintentional weight loss, and signs of vitamin B12 deficiency (low hemoglobin, conjunctival pallor) might raise concern for exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, which is treated with pancreatic enzyme supplementation. However, in exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, an intestinal biopsy would be normal, with preserved villous architecture.
questions.hint: This patient's duodenal biopsy shows villous flattening, elongated and hyperplastic crypts of Lieberkuhn, and lymphocytic infiltration of the lamina propria.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for the evaluation of belly pain and a pruritic skin rash on her shoulders for the last 6 months. She describes feeling bloated after meals. Over the past 3 months, she has had multiple loose bowel movements per day. She appears thin. She is at the 20th percentile for height and 8th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival pallor and inflammation of the corners of the mouth. There are several tense, grouped subepidermal blisters on the shoulders bilaterally. The abdomen is soft, and there is diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multinucleated trophozoites in stool are characteristic of giardia infection, which can also cause abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, and malabsorption. However, the infection tends to self-resolve within a few weeks, and this patient has no history that indicates exposure to the waterborne parasite (e.g., drinking river water while camping). Giardia infection is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased serum lipase is typically seen in acute pancreatitis, which can also present with abdominal pain. The classic presentation is severe epigastric pain that radiates toward the back, worsening after meals; colicky episodes are present when caused by gallstones. Instead of diarrhea, acute pancreatitis can result in ileus (due to inflammation), fever, and a distended or elastic abdomen on palpation. Finally, this patient has no risk factors for acute pancreatitis such as a history of gallstones, alcohol abuse, medication use, viral infections, or congenital disease.

Acute pancreatitis usually presents with increased serum lipase, whereas chronic pancreatitis often shows normal levels of pancreatic enzymes due to the advanced tissue destruction and fibrosis seen in the pancreas.

C) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the terminal ileum is a hallmark feature of Crohn's disease, which can also present with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, features of malabsorption, and dermatologic diseases (e.g., erythema nodosum, acrodermatitis enteropathica). However, it is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis. This patient has celiac disease, which is associated with inflammatory changes in the duodenum and proximal jejunum, not the terminal ileum.

D) INCORRECT:

Esophageal webs occur in Plummer-Vinson syndrome, which is also associated with iron deficiency anemia. However, this disease is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis, as seen here. Also, patients with Plummer-Vinson syndrome usually present with dysphagia, burning sensations of the tongue, and may also have an atrophic and smooth tongue on examination.

E) INCORRECT:

PAS-positive macrophages within the mucosa of the small intestine are the diagnostic hallmark of Whipple disease. Although patients with Whipple disease may also experience abdominal pain and malabsorption, this condition is primarily found in middle-aged men following infection withTropheryma whipplei, and it is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.

F) CORRECT:

Serological testing for IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies is the preferred initial test for diagnosing celiac disease. The exact role of the antibody in the pathophysiology of celiac disease is unknown; in addition to the initial diagnosis, an antibody test is also useful for follow-up. Antibody levels start to decline and usually normalize within 3–12 months following the introduction of a gluten-free diet. Other antibodies that are often present in patients with celiac disease include deamidated gliadin peptide antibodies and anti-endomysial antibodies. Confirmatory testing consists of upper endoscopy with duodenal biopsy, which would show intraepithelial lymphocytic infiltration, crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy.
Image Description:

The ingestion of gliadin, a component of gluten, leads to an immune response in the intestinal epithelium in individuals with celiac disease. Gliadin is deamidated by tissue transglutaminase (tTG) and then ingested by antigen-presenting cells (APC), which activate T cells via MHC II receptors. The activated T cell then activates plasma cells to release anti-tTG, anti-endomysial, and anti-deamidated gliadin antibodies (which all function as diagnostic markers of celiac disease). T cells also differentiate into TH1 cells, which activate cytoplasmic fibroblasts to release matrix proteases. This leads to the destruction of the intestinal architecture with villus atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and the loss of the brush border.

G) INCORRECT:

The hydrogen breath test would be positive in patients with lactose malabsorption. Although this patient may be consuming dairy products that could cause her abdominal discomfort and loose stools if she has lactose intolerance, the condition is not associated with the skin rash described in this patient.

H) INCORRECT:

Oocysts on acid-fast stain are characteristic of Cryptosporidium infection. Cryptosporidium infection can cause watery diarrhea, but the infection is usually self-limited in immunocompetent hosts and resolves within 1–2 weeks. It is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain and bloating, and features of malabsorption such as failure to thrive and signs of iron deficiency anemia (e.g., conjunctival pallor, angular cheilitis). These features together with dermatitis herpetiformis (several tense, grouped subepidermal blisters) are consistent with the diagnosis of celiac disease. The clinical features of celiac disease can occur at any age but typically begin in early childhood or between 20–40 years of age).

questions.text: A previously healthy 20-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recurrent abdominal cramps, bloating, and diarrhea for the past 4 months. She describes her stools as greasy, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush. During this time she has had a 6-kg (13.2-lb) weight loss. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. Physical examination shows pallor and cheilitis. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Test of the stool for occult blood is negative and stool microscopy reveals no pathogens and no leukocytes. Analysis of a 24-hour stool sample shows 12 g (N < 7) of fat. The patient is asked to consume 25 g of d-xylose. Five hours later, its concentration is measured in urine at 2 g (N = > 4 g/5 h). The test is repeated after a two-week course of rifaximin, but the urinary concentration of d-xylose remains the same. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the colon is the underlying mechanism of ulcerative colitis (UC), which can manifest with recurrent abdominal pain, diarrhea, anemia, and weight loss. UC most frequently occurs in individuals 15–35 years of age. However, because the small intestine is not usually affected in UC, the absorption of nutrients here remains unchanged. Therefore, steatorrhea would be absent and urine d-xylose concentration would be normal. Moreover, patients with UC typically present with bloody stools.

B) INCORRECT:

Lactose intolerance is a very common condition caused by an inability to digest lactose. While it also causes abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea, lactose intolerance is not associated with steatorrhea, anemia, cheilitis, or weight loss. Lactose intolerance does not affect the integrity or absorptive capacity of the small intestinal mucosa, meaning urine d-xylose levels would be normal.

C) INCORRECT:

Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency can manifest with abdominal cramps, steatorrhea, and weight loss due to lipase deficiency. However, pancreatic insufficiency does not alter the integrity or absorptive capacity of the small intestinal mucosa, meaning that urine d-xylose levels would be normal. Moreover, causes of exocrine pancreatic insufficiency like cystic fibrosis and chronic pancreatitis do not typically manifest in this age group.

D) INCORRECT:

Tropheryma whipplei is the causative agent of Whipple disease (WD), a rare multisystem infection. Gastrointestinal symptoms of WD include abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and steatorrhea. As WD affects the absorptive capacity of the small intestine, the d-xylose test would also be positive. However, WD primarily affects men > 40 years of age, and most patients have a history of migratory arthralgias affecting large joints, making another more common condition more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) can manifest with diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. Bacterial proliferation impairs the absorptive capacity of the small intestine, leading to a positive d-xylose test. However, the administration of rifaximin would resolve SIBO, resulting in improved small intestinal absorptive capacity and normal urinary d-xylose levels. Additionally, this patient does not have any predisposing factors for SIBO such as blind loop syndrome, intestinal strictures (e.g., postoperative, tuberculosis, Crohn disease), or conditions that decrease intestinal motility (e.g., chronic diabetes mellitus, scleroderma).

F) CORRECT:

Hypersensitivity to gliadin is the underlying cause of celiac disease, which manifests with steatorrhea, weight loss, and features of iron deficiency (pallor and cheilitis). Malabsorption, supported by a positive d-xylose test (carbohydrate malabsorption), high fecal fat content (fat malabsorption), and low hemoglobin (micronutrient malabsorption), is typical of celiac disease. A d-xylose test that remains positive after a course of antibiotics indicates a noninfectious cause of malabsorption.

The gold standard for diagnosing celiac disease is the measurement of serum IgA anti‑tissue transglutaminase antibodies (tTG) and total IgA. If total IgA is normal and IgA tTG is high, an endoscopy-guided intestinal biopsy should be obtained (while the patient is still on a diet that contains gluten) to confirm the diagnosis.
questions.hint: D-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the small intestinal mucosa without enzymatic breakdown and is primarily excreted via urine. After consumption of d-xylose, urinary levels of this monosaccharide typically increase. Loss of absorptive capacity of the small intestinal mucosa leads to a low urinary d-xylose concentration, known as a positive d-xylose test.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of diarrhea, flatulence, and fatigue. She reports having 3–5 episodes of loose stools daily that have an oily appearance. The symptoms are worse after eating. She also complains of an itchy rash on her elbows and knees. A photograph of the rash is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malabsorptive conditions that cause macrocytic, hypochromic anemia due to vitamin B12 and/or folate deficiency include tropical sprue, atrophic gastritis, and chronic pancreatitis. Celiac disease causes malabsorption of iron in the duodenum and may result in a microcytic, hypochromic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased fecal elastase levels are seen in patients with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (e.g., from chronic pancreatitis). Although this condition can manifest with diarrhea and flatulence, it is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis. In addition, patients with chronic pancreatitis typically have epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back and improves upon leaning forward (though in the later stages of chronic pancreatitis, patients may not have any pain).

C) INCORRECT:

Biopsy results that show PAS-positive intestinal macrophages confirm a diagnosis of Whipple disease. Although this condition can manifest with diarrhea and flatulence, it is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis. In addition, this patient lacks other characteristic findings of Whipple disease, such as sacroiliitis, polyserositis, and/or lymphadenopathy.

D) CORRECT:

HLA-DQ2 is a cell surface receptor of antigen-presenting cells associated with 90–95% of cases of celiac disease. Expression of HLA-DQ2 is thought to predispose patients to celiac disease due to increased binding of gluten peptides to this HLA subtype, triggering a T-cell mediated autoimmune reaction and inflammation of the intestinal epithelium. Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with celiac disease and is caused by deposition of IgA and complement C3 in dermal papillae of the dermis.
Image Description:

The ingestion of gliadin, a component of gluten, leads to an immune response in the intestinal epithelium in individuals with celiac disease. Gliadin is deamidated by tissue transglutaminase (tTG) and then ingested by antigen-presenting cells (APC), which activate T cells via MHC II receptors. The activated T cell then activates plasma cells to release anti-tTG, anti-endomysial, and anti-deamidated gliadin antibodies (which all function as diagnostic markers of celiac disease). T cells also differentiate into TH1 cells, which activate cytoplasmic fibroblasts to release matrix proteases. This leads to the destruction of the intestinal architecture with villus atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and the loss of the brush border.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevation in exhaled hydrogen concentration when performing a lactose or hydrogen breath test is seen in patients with lactose malabsorption or small intestinal bacterial overgrowth. Although both of these conditions can manifest with diarrhea and flatulence, neither is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.

F) INCORRECT:

Elevation in urine tryptophan levels is seen in patients with Hartnup disease. This condition can cause diarrhea and a skin rash (due to niacin deficiency); however, the typical rash involves the neck (Casal necklace) and manifests with hyperpigmentation of sun-exposed areas. In addition, patients with Hartnup disease often develop features of dementia and glossitis, which this patient does not have.
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.
questions.hint: This woman's rash is consistent with dermatitis herpetiformis and her symptoms of malabsorption (e.g., fatty diarrhea, flatulence, fatigue) are suggestive of celiac disease.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of an 8-month history of fatigue, intermittent postprandial abdominal bloating and discomfort, foul-smelling, watery diarrhea, and a 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss. She developed a pruritic rash on her knees 3 days ago. Physical examination shows several tense, excoriated vesicles on the knees bilaterally. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.2 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 76 μm3. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Granulomatous inflammation of the terminal ileum

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Testing for IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies is the gold standard for diagnosing celiac disease and is also useful in monitoring a patient's response to treatment, as antibody levels start to decline and usually normalize 3–12 months following the introduction of a gluten-free diet. Although celiac disease can occur at any age, it most commonly manifests either in early childhood or between 20–40 years of age.
Image Description:

The ingestion of gliadin, a component of gluten, leads to an immune response in the intestinal epithelium in individuals with celiac disease. Gliadin is deamidated by tissue transglutaminase (tTG) and then ingested by antigen-presenting cells (APC), which activate T cells via MHC II receptors. The activated T cell then activates plasma cells to release anti-tTG, anti-endomysial, and anti-deamidated gliadin antibodies (which all function as diagnostic markers of celiac disease). T cells also differentiate into TH1 cells, which activate cytoplasmic fibroblasts to release matrix proteases. This leads to the destruction of the intestinal architecture with villus atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and the loss of the brush border.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue protruding into the esophagus. They occur in Plummer-Vinson syndrome, which is associated with iron deficiency anemia. However, patients with Plummer-Vinson syndrome usually present with dysphagia and a burning sensation of the tongue; they can have an atrophic, smooth tongue on exam. Plummer-Vinson syndrome is not associated with abdominal pain, diarrhea, or dermatitis herpetiformis.

C) INCORRECT:

Oocysts on acid-fast stain are seen in infection with Cryptosporidium, which can cause watery diarrhea. However, the infection is usually self-limited in immunocompetent hosts and resolves within 1–2 weeks. It is not associated with malabsorption or dermatitis herpetiformis.

D) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous intestinal inflammation, especially in the terminal ileum, is characteristic of Crohn disease, which can manifest with abdominal pain, symptoms of malabsorption such as iron deficiency anemia, and dermatologic diseases (e.g., erythema nodosum, acrodermatitis enteropathica). However, it is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.

E) INCORRECT:

The finding of Periodic acid-Schiff-positive (PAS-positive) macrophages within the mucosa of the small intestine is the diagnostic hallmark of Whipple disease. Although patients with Whipple disease may also experience abdominal pain and malabsorption, this condition is primarily found in middle-aged men following infection with Tropheryma whipplei, and it is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.

F) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum amylase concentration is a nonspecific sign of acute pancreatitis, which can present with abdominal pain. The classic presentation is severe epigastric pain that radiates toward the back, worsening after meals; colicky episodes are present in gallstone pancreatitis. However, diarrhea is not usually seen in acute pancreatitis. Ileus (due to inflammation), fever, and a distended or elastic abdomen on palpation are common features of acute pancreatitis not seen in this patient. Finally, this patient has no risk factors for acute pancreatitis such as a history of gallstones, alcohol abuse, medication use, viral infections, or congenital disease.

G) INCORRECT:

Multinucleated trophozoites in stool are characteristic of infection with Giardia, which can also cause abdominal pain, diarrhea, and malabsorption. However, the infection tends to self-resolve within a few weeks, and this patient has no history that indicates exposure to the waterborne parasite (e.g., drinking river water while camping). Infection with Giardia is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.

H) INCORRECT:

The hydrogen breath test is positive in patients with lactose malabsorption, which can cause postprandial abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, lactose malabsorption does not cause anemia and is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.
questions.hint: Postprandial abdominal discomfort and bloating, chronic diarrhea, and severe microcytic anemia (likely secondary to iron deficiency) point to a malabsorptive syndrome. The additional presence of dermatitis herpetiformis (several tense, grouped subepidermal blisters) is strongly suggestive of celiac disease.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue, intermittent abdominal pain, and bulky, foul-smelling diarrhea. She has had a 4-kg (8-lb 12-oz) weight loss during this period despite no changes in appetite. Examination of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Staining of the stool with Sudan III stain shows a large number of red droplets. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis (UC) can manifest with recurring episodes of diarrhea, intermittent abdominal pain, fatigue (due to anemia), and weight loss (due to recurrent inflammation and anorexia). However, patients with UC would also have symptoms such as tenesmus and mucoid or bloody stools (hematochezia), which are not reported in this patient. Fat malabsorption and steatorrhea are unusual in UC because the small intestine, which is the site of fat absorption, is usually spared.

Fat malabsorption and steatorrhea are more common with Crohn disease, which often affects the small intestine. Rarely, ileal involvement can occur in UC due to “backwash ileitis”.

B) INCORRECT:

Carcinoid syndrome can cause diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. However, carcinoid syndrome would not cause fat malabsorption and steatorrhea, and affected individuals commonly present with additional symptoms, such as cutaneous flushing, wheezing, and dyspnea, none of which are present here.

C) INCORRECT:

Symptomatic intestinal amebiasis would result in abdominal pain but fever and bloody diarrhea rather than steatorrhea would be expected, and stool examination would show trophozoites with engulfed erythrocytes or cysts with 1–4 nuclei. Moreover, the organism that causes amebiasis, E. histolytica, is most commonly found in tropical and subtropical regions, and this patient does not report any recent travel history.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fresh stool mount (trichrome stain; very high magnification)

Three trophozoites are visible, two with phagocytosed erythrocytes that appear as dark ovoid inclusions (examples indicated by yellow overlay). The trophozoites have a single nucleus (examples indicated by blue overlay) that contains a small karyosome (examples indicated by arrowheads), surrounded by evenly distributed peripheral chromatin (examples indicated by arrows).

This appearance indicates E. histolytica, which is differentiated from the nonpathogenic E. dispar by its erythrophagocytic capacity.

D) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) can manifest with altered bowel movements (diarrhea or constipation) and abdominal cramping but weight loss, steatorrhea, and fatigue would not occur with irritable bowel syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Lactose malabsorption can cause intermittent abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, individuals with lactose intolerance usually describe a direct connection between consumption of dairy products and onset of symptoms and complain of significant flatulence. Moreover, lactose malabsorption alone would not cause fat malabsorption and steatorrhea.

F) CORRECT:

Celiac disease (CD) is an inflammatory autoimmune condition caused by hypersensitivity to gliadin. It predominantly affects the duodenum and jejunum and is characterized by villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytosis. Patients are often asymptomatic but can present at any age with gastrointestinal symptoms such as crampy abdominal pain, fat malabsorption, and steatorrhea as well as extraintestinal manifestations (e.g., symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, anemia, depression, dermatitis herpetiformis). Patients with celiac disease are often positive for IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase, anti-endomysial, and anti-deamidated gliadin peptide antibodies. Celiac disease is most common among individuals of northern European descent and is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 haplotypes.
questions.hint: Sudan III staining is used to identify lipids in a sample. Foul-smelling diarrhea with fat in the stool (steatorrhea) indicates fat malabsorption.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman, diagnosed with celiac disease at age 20, reports a 1-month history of progressively worsening postprandial epigastric pain and bloating associated with 4.5-kg weight loss. She also notes a low-grade fever, nausea, a diminished ability to keep down both solids and liquids, and nonbloody emesis.
She adheres to a gluten-free diet only intermittently and has occasional mild diarrhea, which she controls with diphenoxylate-atropine. She denies recent travel or antibiotic use.
On physical examination, her abdomen is moderately distended, with tenderness to light palpation over the epigastrium but no guarding. Bowel sounds are present.
An abdominal radiograph shows air-fluid levels in her stomach and duodenum.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with celiac disease are at increased risk for malignancies, including enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, small-bowel adenocarcinoma, and oropharyngeal and esophageal cancers.

Enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma is usually indicated by relapse of symptoms of celiac disease, including diarrhea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and unexplained fever. Incidence peaks in the sixth decade of life, and the lymphoma usually develops in the jejunum, although it may be found in the ileum or extraintestinal sites (e.g., liver, brain, chest, or bone). The prognosis is poor.

Key learning point: The intestinal malignancy that is most associated with celiac disease is T-cell lymphoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Refractory celiac disease is characterized by persistent celiac disease symptoms and villous atrophy despite strict adherence to a gluten-free diet; it can be associated with ulcerative jejunitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Refractory celiac disease is characterized by persistent celiac disease symptoms and villous atrophy despite strict adherence to a gluten-free diet; it can be associated with ulcerative jejunitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal stromal tumor and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome are not associated with celiac disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal stromal tumor and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome are not associated with celiac disease.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman reports 6 months of loose, nonbloody stools with associated bloating and abdominal cramping. She has not traveled outside the United States recently. She has tried eliminating dairy foods from her diet, but it did not improve her symptoms.
On physical examination, her abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation. Skin examination reveals no rashes. Laboratory testing reveals a hematocrit of 32.0% (reference range, 36.0–46.0). Stool culture tests for ova and parasites are negative.
Which one of the following tests should be ordered at this time to evaluate for celiac disease?

choices.text: Measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody and total IgA
Human leukocyte antigen DQ2 and DQ8 test

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody (tTG-IgA) is the preferred initial test for celiac disease because of its high sensitivity (94%) and specificity (97%). This test should be performed with a measurement of serum IgA to ensure that a false-negative test result is not due to IgA deficiency. Tissue transglutaminase IgG antibody testing has widely variable sensitivity and specificity for celiac disease. It is indicated for patients with IgA deficiency.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial test for celiac disease is measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody and total IgA.

B) INCORRECT:

Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) DQ2 and DQ8 testing has a high negative predictive value for celiac disease but poor specificity. Ninety percent of patients with celiac disease express the DQ2 haplotype, and 5% express the DQ8 haplotype. HLA testing is typically performed when histology is consistent with celiac disease but the serologic testing is negative.

C) INCORRECT:

All patients with positive serologic testing should undergo endoscopy before initiating a gluten-free diet, but endoscopy is not the initial test; it is performed after serologic tests have been obtained.

D) INCORRECT:

Deamidated gliadin peptide antibody-IgG tests are not routinely recommended for evaluation of celiac disease because they have lower sensitivity and specificity than tTG-IgA testing or endomysial IgA antibody testing.

E) INCORRECT:

Although endomysial IgA antibody tests are nearly 100% specific for celiac disease, they are expensive and operator-dependent. Consequently, they are generally reserved for confirmation of borderline positive test results or to investigate presumed false-positive results on tTG-IgA tests. False-positive tests for celiac disease can occur in patients with other autoimmune diseases, such as type 1 diabetes.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man is hospitalized with acute pain in the left groin after slipping on ice. Radiography confirms acute fracture of the left femoral neck. His medical history includes type 1 diabetes since the age of 14 years, vitiligo that developed in his thirties, and primary hypothyroidism since the age of 45 years.
The patient’s pain is controlled, and a full physical examination is performed. His heart rate is 88 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. His left leg is externally rotated.
Laboratory blood testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



25-hydroxyvitamin D (ng/mL)
9
30–80


Calcium (mg/dL)

9.3

9.0–10.5


Albumin (g/dL)
4.0
3.5–5.5


Parathyroid hormone (pg/mL)
84
10–60


Total testosterone (ng/dL)
305

Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.0

Bone mineral density screening by means of dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry is notable for T scores of −2.8 for the right femoral neck and−2.5 for L1–L4.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although hypogonadism may result in bone loss, age-related decline in testosterone levels (resulting in total testosterone levels that are normal for age) cannot explain clinically significant osteoporosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma should be ruled out in a workup for secondary causes of osteoporosis, which may be associated with a low albumin level and hypercalcemia.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has secondary hyperparathyroidism, given that his calcium level is normal and he has an elevated parathyroid hormone level. The most common cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism is a low vitamin D level, such as occurs with malabsorptive diseases.

D) INCORRECT:

Although hypogonadism may result in bone loss, age-related decline in testosterone levels (resulting in total testosterone levels that are normal for age) cannot explain clinically significant osteoporosis.

E) CORRECT:

Clinically significant osteoporosis and fragility fractures in men younger than 70 years should prompt a workup for potential secondary causes of excessive bone loss. Celiac disease can develop without warning in young adults and in older patients. Many patients have asymptomatic celiac disease that is nevertheless associated with osteopenia or osteoporosis. Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibodies are both sensitive and specific for celiac disease.

This patient has secondary hyperparathyroidism, given that his calcium level is normal and he has an elevated parathyroid hormone level. The most common cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism is a low vitamin D level, such as occurs with malabsorptive diseases.

Key learning point: The combination of severe vitamin D deficiency and osteoporosis in an older patient with a history of autoimmune endocrine diseases should prompt an evaluation for celiac disease.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with a history of Addison disease and primary hypothyroidism presents for routine follow-up. She has been taking hydrocortisone, fludrocortisone, and levothyroxine.
She reports mild fatigue that does not affect her daily activities and a pruritic rash on the extensor surface of her knees that consists of small clusters of scattered erythematous papules and vesicles. She has not had fever, chills, night sweats, change in weight, dizziness, palpitations, intolerance to heat or cold, nausea or vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, constipation, polyuria, or polydipsia.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value

Leukocyte count (per mm3)
5700
4500–11,000



Hemoglobin (g/dL)

Hematocrit (%)

285,000

Which one of the following measurements is most appropriate for further evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody and total IgA

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Because the patient is already treated with levothyroxine for her hypothyroidism, measurement of the anti-thyroid-peroxidase antibody level will not result in a change in her therapy.

B) CORRECT:

Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome (APS) type II is diagnosed based on the presence of Addison disease together with either hypothyroidism or type 1 diabetes. Patients with APS should be monitored for the development of associated conditions. Because celiac disease is associated with APS type II, it should be tested for if there are any signs or symptoms of concern.

In this case, the patient has a rash consistent with dermatitis herpetiformis as well as microcytic anemia and vitamin D deficiency, so evaluation for celiac disease is warranted. Initial serology should include measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody (tTG-IgA) and total IgA (to exclude the possibility of a false-negative tTG-IgA result from IgA deficiency).

Key learning point: The syndrome characterized by the presence of both Addison disease and hypothyroidism is autoimmune polyglandular syndrome type II.

C) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome type II is not associated with elevated levels of anti-citrullinated peptide antibody, anti-Ro antibody, or antinuclear antibody (which are associated with rheumatoid arthritis, Sjögren syndrome, and systemic lupus erythematosus, respectively).

D) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome type II is not associated with elevated levels of anti-citrullinated peptide antibody, anti-Ro antibody, or antinuclear antibody (which are associated with rheumatoid arthritis, Sjögren syndrome, and systemic lupus erythematosus, respectively).

E) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome type II is not associated with elevated levels of anti-citrullinated peptide antibody, anti-Ro antibody, or antinuclear antibody (which are associated with rheumatoid arthritis, Sjögren syndrome, and systemic lupus erythematosus, respectively).

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman with hypothyroidism and type 1 diabetes presents to the emergency department with weakness, malaise, and abdominal discomfort. She also reports an unintended weight loss of 6.8 kg during the past year. Her only medications are insulin aspart via an insulin pump, levothyroxine 200 μg daily, and an oral contraceptive pill. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs. She rarely drinks alcohol. Her mother and sister also have hypothyroidism.
Her height is 160 cm, her weight is 50 kg, and her BMI is 19.5. Her blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 75 beats per minute. Other physical examination findings are unremarkable.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:

Which one of the following diagnostic tests is indicated for this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody and total IgA

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A gastric emptying study can diagnose delayed gastric emptying or gastroparesis, which can be a complication of poorly controlled diabetes (this patient’s diabetes is well controlled). Furthermore, gastroparesis should not cause malabsorption and thus would not lead to microcytic anemia and vitamin D deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

An elevated thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin level in a patient with hyperthyroidism is suggestive of Graves disease. This patient’s thyroid-stimulating hormone level is normal.

C) CORRECT:

Unintended weight loss, abdominal symptoms, microcytic anemia, and vitamin D deficiency are suggestive of malabsorption. Celiac disease should be considered in a patient with these symptoms who has type 1 diabetes and hypothyroidism. Both autoimmune thyroid disease and type 1 diabetes are associated with celiac disease. All three conditions could also be part of an autoimmune polyglandular syndrome.

Initial serology should include measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody (tTG-IgA) and total IgA (to exclude the possibility of a false-negative tTG-IgA result from IgA deficiency). If the tTG-IgA test is positive, the patient should be referred to a gastroenterologist for confirmation of the diagnosis, typically with upper endoscopy and small-bowel biopsy. Management of celiac disease involves adherence to a gluten-free diet and correction of associated micronutrient deficiencies.

Key learning point: The most common gastrointestinal condition associated with type 1 diabetes and autoimmune thyroid disease is celiac disease.

D) INCORRECT:

An adrenocorticotropin stimulation test is used to diagnose adrenal insufficiency. The patient’s autoimmune conditions may put her at risk for adrenal insufficiency, but a morning cortisol level >10 μg/dL argues against this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

An endoscopic ultrasound of the pancreas can be used to diagnose pancreatic tumors in a patient whose symptoms suggest that possibility.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman reports a 2-month history of persistent epigastric pain and two to three loose, nonbloody stools per day. There is no steatorrhea. She has lost 4 kg of body weight during the past year and now weighs 63 kg; she is 164 cm tall. She also complains of a very itchy rash on her elbows and knees.
Her medical history is significant for intermittent iron-deficiency anemia that has not responded well to iron supplementation with 200 mg daily of elemental iron. She has intermittently suffered from constipation.
She travelled with her family to El Salvador 4 months ago.
Examination of the abdomen reveals mild epigastric tenderness without rebound or guarding. There are excoriated erythematous papules and ruptured vesicles on the extensor surfaces of her knees and elbows (figure). There are no perianal lesions. The remaining physical examination and vital signs are within normal limits.
Her stools are negative for occult blood.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Shigellosis may be a concern in a returning traveler, but the duration of symptoms in this case is too long for shigellosis. Shigellosis typically lasts 5 to 7 days and often progresses to bloody diarrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease can result in secondary lactose intolerance due to duodenal villous blunting. However, primary lactose intolerance is not associated with weight loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Amebiasis typically causes diarrhea with subacute onset but is not associated with a rash that has the features of dermatitis herpetiformis.

D) CORRECT:

Celiac disease is relatively common, with a prevalence of nearly 1% worldwide. Abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss make up the classic triad of symptoms, but they are not always present. Celiac disease may also manifest with constipation, abnormal liver enzyme levels, vomiting, osteoporosis, or iron-deficiency anemia. Long-term complications of celiac disease include neuropathy, ataxia, hyposplenism, and infertility.

This patient's rash suggests dermatitis herpetiformis, which is closely associated with celiac disease. The rash is not always present, but it strongly suggests celiac disease when it is. Dermatitis herpetiformis typically appears on the extensor surfaces of the body, most notably on the elbow and knee joints, and is characterized by pruritic papules and vesicles that are grouped together (“herpetiform”). Other common locations include the buttocks and occasionally the trunk. A skin biopsy is required to confirm the diagnosis.

Key learning point: The most likely gastrointestinal diagnosis in a 20-year-old woman with abdominal pain, diarrhea, weight loss, and a pruritic rash on the elbows and knees is celiac disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Crohn disease could explain the gastrointestinal symptoms seen in this patient. However, the presence of dermatitis herpetiformis makes celiac disease far more likely in this patient than Crohn disease. Although patients with Crohn disease can present with a rash, the more classic skin manifestations are erythema nodosum (tender, red nodules, typically on the shins) and pyoderma gangrenosum (small, red papules or pustules that eventually evolve into ulcerative lesions).

questions.text:
A previously healthy 34-year-old woman reports that for the past few months, she has felt increasingly tired throughout the day. She swims laps in the pool several times per week but has had to cut the number of laps in half because of intense fatigue. She also reports a 1.5-kg weight loss during the past 5 months despite a normal appetite and unchanged dietary habits. A review of systems is positive for abdominal bloating and discomfort with occasional diarrhea. She has not had any bloody or tarry stools.
Her vital signs are normal. On physical examination, she appears thin with conjunctival and sublingual pallor. Cardiac examination reveals a faint systolic ejection murmur. Lung, abdominal, and perianal examinations are unremarkable. Rectal examination is normal.
Initial laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
9200
4500–11,000


Erythrocyte count (per mm3)
4910
4000–5200


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8.9
12.0–16.0


Hematocrit (%)
24.8
36.0–46.0


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
65
80–100


Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (pg/erythrocyte)
21
26–34

27.7
31.0–37.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
510,000
150,000–350,000


Vitamin B12 (pg/mL)
260
>250


Folate (ng/mL)
8.0
3.1–17.5


Additional blood testing is positive for tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibodies and reveals a normal total IgA level.
Upper endoscopic studies are performed to confirm the diagnosis.
Which of the following histopathologic findings are most likely to be seen on biopsies taken from this patient?

choices.text: Patchy neutrophilic duodenitis with occasional granulomas
Esophageal inflammation with more than 20 eosinophils per high-power field
Duodenal villous atrophy, intraepithelial lymphocytosis, and crypt hyperplasia
Lymphocytic infiltration of gastric tissue with spiral-shaped bacteria visible on hematoxylin and eosin staining
Mucosal atrophy of the fundus of the stomach, sparing the antrum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Given this patient’s weight loss, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, Crohn disease could be considered in the differential diagnosis, but the presence of tTG-IgA makes celiac disease more likely. Endoscopic biopsies in a patient with Crohn disease may demonstrate a neutrophilic infiltrate with occasional granulomas in the esophagus, stomach, and/or duodenum. Inflammation is often transmural, but this would not be visualized via punch biopsy.

B) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic esophagitis is a chronic allergic inflammatory disease affecting the esophagus. Symptoms often include dysphagia, heartburn, and upper abdominal or chest pain, none of which are present in this patient. Biopsies of the esophagus in patients with this condition reveal inflammation and extensive eosinophilic infiltration of the epithelium.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation and laboratory findings (consistent with iron-deficiency anemia) raise concern for a malabsorptive disorder. Abdominal bloating, weight loss, and distention are classic symptoms of celiac disease.

Celiac disease results from a T cell-mediated immune response to gliadin, a fraction of gluten found in products derived from wheat, barley, and rye. The resulting inflammation damages the small intestine and impairs absorption of nutrients, including iron. Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibodies (tTG-IgA) are highly sensitive and specific for celiac disease.

This patient’s constellation of symptoms and serologic testing strongly suggests celiac disease. Nevertheless, endoscopic studies are recommended as confirmation and to rule out other diagnoses. Histopathology in celiac disease classically reveals intraepithelial lymphocytosis, crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy of the duodenum.

Key learning point: In a patient with celiac disease, duodenal biopsies are most likely to reveal intraepithelial lymphocytosis, crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

Helicobacter pylori is a gram-negative bacterium that colonizes the gastric epithelium and can cause gastritis, ulcers, and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma. Gastric biopsy with hematoxylin and eosin staining will demonstrate the presence of spiral-shaped bacteria with lymphocytic infiltration.

E) INCORRECT:

Mucosal atrophy of the fundus of the stomach, which houses parietal cells, is a classic finding in pernicious anemia. Pernicious anemia is caused by a deficiency of vitamin B12 due to a deficiency of intrinsic factor, a protein required for absorption of vitamin B12 . It is characterized by autoimmune destruction of the parietal cells of the stomach, which produce intrinsic factor. The clinical presentation is often insidious and includes symptoms of anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency, which this patient does not have. Pernicious anemia generally manifests with a macrocytic anemia (rather than the microcytic anemia seen in this patient), with a mean corpuscular volume greater than 100 μm3 .

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy who has been tracking along the 10th percentile for height and weight presents for routine evaluation. During the past year, he has grown 1 cm and is now below the 5th percentile for height. He remains at the 10th percentile for weight. He reports having episodes of diarrhea with foul-smelling stools.
His heart rate is 82 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals white spots on his incisors. There is no goiter. His abdominal examination is normal. Testicular development and pubic hair are consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 3.
Which one of the following laboratory tests is most likely to be abnormal in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measuring follicle-stimulating hormone levels is helpful in the evaluation of delayed puberty but is not usually helpful in the evaluation of short stature or growth failure. This patient is progressing through puberty normally, with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 3 at 14 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Zinc deficiency can cause a watery diarrhea but is rare and is most typically seen in older children with chronic diseases such as Crohn disease, sickle cell disease, or liver disease. Other common symptoms of zinc deficiency include a depressed immune system, impairment of taste and smell, and night blindness.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient’s declining growth velocity might suggest hypothyroidism, the patient also reports diarrhea rather than constipation, and the physical examination identified dental enamel defects, which are more suggestive of celiac disease. Furthermore, weight gain would be expected with hypothyroidism.

D) CORRECT:

Celiac disease is the most likely diagnosis in an adolescent with sudden growth failure (decreased growth velocity), dental enamel defects, and chronic diarrhea consisting of foul-smelling, bulky stools.

Celiac disease is estimated to affect up to 1% of the population. Approximately 50% of patients with this disease experience weight loss, chronic diarrhea, and abdominal distention. Older children are more likely to present with extraintestinal manifestations, including enamel defects, dermatitis herpetiformis, osteopenia, short stature, delayed puberty, and iron-deficiency anemia; these findings can occur in the absence of other, more-typical symptoms of celiac disease.

The preferred initial test for celiac disease is measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody while the patient is on a gluten-containing diet. Total IgA levels should be measured at the same time to ensure that the patient is not IgA-deficient. The diagnosis is subsequently confirmed by upper endoscopy and duodenal biopsy. Although improvement of symptoms on a gluten-free diet can suggest celiac disease, histologic confirmation is recommended given the long-term burden of such a diet.

Key learning point: Growth velocity deceleration associated with diarrhea and tooth enamel defects in an adolescent is most likely due to celiac disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) is produced in the liver, and low levels reflect growth-hormone deficiency. Although patients with growth-hormone deficiency will present with short stature, they do not tend to have gastrointestinal symptoms or dental enamel defects.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl reports a 2-month history of persistent epigastric pain and two to three loose, nonbloody stools per day. There is no steatorrhea. She has lost 4 kg of body weight during the past year and now weighs 62 kg; she is 163 cm tall. She also complains of a very itchy rash on her elbows and knees.

E) INCORRECT:

Crohn disease could explain the gastrointestinal symptoms seen in this patient. However, it is more often associated with bloody diarrhea. The presence of dermatitis herpetiformis makes celiac disease far more likely in this patient than Crohn disease. Although patients with Crohn disease can present with a rash, the more classic skin manifestations are erythema nodosum (tender, red to violaceous nodules, typically on the shins) and pyoderma gangrenosum (small, red papules or pustules that eventually evolve into ulcerative lesions).

questions.text:
A previously healthy 14-year-old girl reports that for the past few months, she has felt increasingly tired throughout the day. She plays on her school soccer team but has had to sit out of several games because she feels like she “can’t keep up.” She also reports a 1.5-kg weight loss during the past 5 months despite a normal appetite and unchanged dietary habits. A review of systems is positive for abdominal bloating and discomfort with occasional diarrhea. She has not had any bloody or tarry stools.
Her vital signs are normal. On physical examination, she appears thin with conjunctival and sublingual pallor. Cardiac examination reveals a faint systolic ejection murmur. Lung, abdominal, and perianal examinations are unremarkable. A stool guaiac test is negative.
Initial laboratory testing yields the following results:

Additional blood testing is positive for tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibodies and reveals a normal total IgA level.
Upper endoscopic studies are performed to confirm the diagnosis.
Which of the following histopathologic findings are most likely to be seen on biopsies taken from this patient?

choices.text: Normal villous architecture in the duodenum with a mild increase in intraepithelial lymphocytes
Mucosal atrophy of the fundus of the stomach, sparing the antrum
Patchy neutrophilic duodenitis with occasional granulomas
Duodenal villous atrophy, intraepithelial lymphocytosis, and crypt hyperplasia
Lymphocytic infiltration of gastric tissue with spiral-shaped bacteria visible on hematoxylin and eosin staining

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A mild increase in duodenal intraepithelial lymphocytes could be seen in early stages of celiac disease, but this is a fairly nonspecific finding and could represent a number of other conditions, including small-intestinal bacterial overgrowth.

B) INCORRECT:

Mucosal atrophy of the fundus of the stomach, which houses parietal cells, is a classic finding in pernicious anemia. Pernicious anemia is caused by a deficiency of vitamin B12 due to a deficiency of intrinsic factor, a protein required for absorption of vitamin B12. It is characterized by autoimmune destruction of the parietal cells of the stomach, which produce intrinsic factor. The clinical presentation is often insidious. Pernicious anemia generally manifests with macrocytic anemia (rather than the microcytic anemia seen in this patient), with a mean corpuscular volume greater than 100 μm3.

C) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic biopsies in a patient with Crohn disease may demonstrate a neutrophilic infiltrate with occasional granulomas in the esophagus, stomach, and/or duodenum. Inflammation is often transmural, but this would not be visualized via pinch biopsy. Given this patient’s weight loss, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, Crohn disease could be considered in the differential diagnosis, but the presence of tTG-IgA makes celiac disease more likely.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation and laboratory findings (consistent with iron-deficiency anemia) raise concern for a malabsorptive disorder. Abdominal bloating, weight loss, and distention are classic symptoms of celiac disease.

Celiac disease results from a T cell-mediated immune response to gliadin, a fraction of gluten found in products derived from wheat, barley, and rye. The resulting inflammation damages the small intestine and impairs absorption of nutrients, including iron. Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibodies (tTG-IgA) are highly sensitive and specific for celiac disease.

This patient’s constellation of symptoms and serologic testing strongly suggests celiac disease. Nevertheless, endoscopic studies are recommended as confirmation and to rule out other diagnoses. Histopathology in celiac disease classically reveals intraepithelial lymphocytosis, crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy of the duodenum.

Key learning point: In a patient with celiac disease, duodenal biopsies are most likely to reveal intraepithelial lymphocytosis, crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy.

E) INCORRECT:

Helicobacter pylori is a gram-negative bacterium that colonizes the gastric epithelium and gastric biopsy with hematoxylin and eosin staining will demonstrate the presence of spiral-shaped bacteria with lymphocytic infiltration. Helicobacter pylori infection can cause gastritis, ulcers, and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma but children with Helicobacter pylori infection are often asymptomatic and rarely develop complications. The presence of tTG-IgA makes celiac disease more likely.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl reports 6 months of loose, nonbloody stools with associated bloating and abdominal cramping. She has not traveled outside the United States recently. She has tried eliminating dairy foods from her diet, but it did not improve her symptoms.
On physical examination, her abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation. Skin examination reveals no rashes. Her hematocrit is 32% (reference range, 36–46). Stool culture tests for ova and parasites are negative.
Which one of the following tests is the most reasonable next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody and total IgA
Human leukocyte antigen DQ2 and DQ8 test

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Celiac disease should be considered in patients with chronic diarrhea and anemia. The anemia associated with celiac disease is typically microcytic due to iron deficiency, but macrocytic anemia due to vitamin deficiencies is also seen.

Measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibodies (tTG-IgA) is the preferred initial test for celiac disease because of its high sensitivity (94%) and specificity (97%). This test should be performed together with a measurement of serum IgA to ensure that a false-negative test result is not due to IgA deficiency.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial test for celiac disease is measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody and total IgA.

B) INCORRECT:

Although Helicobacter pylori infection can cause upper gastrointestinal symptoms, diarrhea is not typically attributed to H. pylori.

C) INCORRECT:

Deamidated gliadin peptide antibody-IgG tests are not routinely recommended for evaluation of celiac disease because they have lower sensitivity and specificity than tTG-IgA testing or endomysial IgA antibody testing. Tissue transglutaminase IgG antibody testing, which has widely variable sensitivity and specificity for celiac disease, is indicated for patients with IgA deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) DQ2 and DQ8 testing has a high negative predictive value for celiac disease but poor specificity. Ninety percent of patients with celiac disease express the DQ2 haplotype, and 5% express the DQ8 haplotype. HLA testing is typically performed when histology is consistent with celiac disease but the serologic testing is negative.

E) INCORRECT:

Although food intolerances might contribute to diarrhea, the workup to identify a food intolerance would not traditionally include food-specific IgE levels, because the utility of such testing is much lower in the absence of classic IgE-mediated symptoms.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with hypothyroidism and type 1 diabetes presents for diabetes follow-up and reports malaise, abdominal discomfort, and unintentional weight loss (6.8 kg) during the past year. Her only medications are insulin aspart via an insulin pump, levothyroxine 100 μg daily, and an oral contraceptive pill. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Her mother and sister also have hypothyroidism.
She weighs 50 kg and is 160 cm tall (BMI, 19.5). Her blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 75 beats per minute. Other physical examination findings are unremarkable.
Fasting morning laboratory studies yield the following results:
